articles.headline: In China, Knockoff Cellphones Are a Hit
articles.snippet: An industry building look-alike mobile phones for as little as $35 is tickling China’s pride in rebellious creativity.
articles.abstract: An industry building look-alike mobile phones for as little as $35 is tickling China’s pride in rebellious creativity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  The phone’s sleek lines and touch-screen keyboard are unmistakably familiar. So is the logo on the back. But a sales clerk at a sprawling electronic goods market in this Chinese coastal city admits what is clear upon closer inspection: this is not the Apple iPhone; this is the Hi-Phone.

articles.headline: Obama Is Nudging Views on Race, a Survey Finds
articles.snippet: The percentage of blacks who say that race relations are generally good has doubled since last July, a Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.abstract: The percentage of blacks who say that race relations are generally good has doubled since last July, a Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s presidency seems to be altering the public perception of race relations in the United States. Two-thirds of Americans now say race relations are generally good, and the percentage of blacks who say so has doubled since last July, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Italy Seizes Millions in Assets From Four Banks
articles.snippet: The banks are being investigated after accusations they misled the city of Milan over a $2.2 billion bond issue and related contracts.
articles.abstract: The banks are being investigated after accusations they misled the city of Milan over a $2.2 billion bond issue and related contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With municipal bond investigations spreading to Europe from the United States, Italian authorities have seized about $300 million in assets of four global banks  JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, UBS and Depfa  whose officials have been accused of fraud.

articles.headline: A Merger of Agencies Shakes Up Hollywood
articles.snippet: The merger of the William Morris and Endeavor agencies is a sign of the fissures produced by the digital revolution and a reaching out for emerging businesses.
articles.abstract: The merger of the William Morris and Endeavor agencies is a sign of the fissures produced by the digital revolution and a reaching out for emerging businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After months of discussion and rumors, two of the entertainment industry’s largest talent agencies, William Morris and Endeavor, agreed on Monday to merge as William Morris Endeavor Entertainment.

articles.headline: U.S. Steps Up Effort on Digital Defenses
articles.snippet: A new international race has begun to develop cyberweapons and systems to protect against them.
articles.abstract: A new international race has begun to develop cyberweapons and systems to protect against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David E. Sanger, John Markoff and Thom Shanker and written by Mr. Sanger.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, John Markoff and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: How ’07 ABC Interview Tilted a Torture Debate
articles.snippet: An official’s claim that waterboarding yielded quick results was widely repeated, but has now been discredited.
articles.abstract: An official’s claim that waterboarding yielded quick results was widely repeated, but has now been discredited.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2007, there was the first crack of daylight into the government’s use of waterboarding during interrogations of Al Qaeda detainees. On Dec. 10, John Kiriakou, a former C.I.A. officer who had participated in the capture of the suspected terrorist Abu Zubaydah in Pakistan in 2002, appeared on ABC News to say that while he considered waterboarding a form of torture, the technique worked and yielded results very quickly.

articles.headline: Verizon Said to Be in Talks for the iPhone
articles.snippet: A version of the iPhone that would work on Verizon’s network could be available as soon as next year.
articles.abstract: A version of the iPhone that would work on Verizon’s network could be available as soon as next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The iPhone may be poised to shake up the cellphone industry a second time.

articles.headline: Stress Tests? No Big Deal After All
articles.snippet: To listen to the government, the tests may be nothing more than a way to gauge how much help a bank will need.
articles.abstract: To listen to the government, the tests may be nothing more than a way to gauge how much help a bank will need.

articles.headline: Phoenix Leads the Way Down in Home Prices
articles.snippet: The price of single-family homes fell in February in 20 major metropolitan areas, including Phoenix, where home prices have fallen by half.
articles.abstract: The price of single-family homes fell in February in 20 major metropolitan areas, including Phoenix, where home prices have fallen by half.
articles.lead_paragraph: Phoenix has achieved the unwelcome distinction of becoming the first major American city where home prices have fallen in half since the market peaked in the middle of the decade, according to data released Tuesday.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Holdouts Jeopardize Debt Plan for Chrysler
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department has told the lenders that they must accept $2 billion in cash to eliminate about $6.9 billion in secured debt by a deadline on Thursday.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department has told the lenders that they must accept $2 billion in cash to eliminate about $6.9 billion in secured debt by a deadline on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Obama administration is prepared to force Chrysler into bankruptcy by the end of the week unless it gets unanimous consent from a group of banks and hedge funds to retire the automaker’s debt.
